title: Pixel flood attack cause the javascript heap out of memory

profile.name: Node.js third-party modules
profile.about: This program is used to handle vulnerabilities in the Node.js ecosystem.

vulnerability_information:
I would like to report Pixel flood attack in jimp
It allows flooding the memory and causing DoS by uploading a crafted image (5kb image), and the Jimp module will tries to allocate 4128062500 pixels into memory.

# Module

**module name:** jimp
**version:** <=0.10.1
**npm page:** `https://www.npmjs.com/package/jimp`

## Module Description

> An image processing library for Node written entirely in JavaScript, with zero native dependencies.

## Module Stats

1,053,700 Weekly Downloads

# Vulnerability

## Vulnerability Description

> The jimp module will load the pixel from the image file to the memory, and processing the image in order to get a new image file such as resize, rotate, blur, etc. The jimp using EXIF data for picture orientation, which was causing run out of memory in the system. The attacker could manipulate the exif data in the image file such as change the image pixel to 64250x64250pixels. If the jimp module loaded the crafted image, it tries to allocate 4128062500 pixels into memory. 

## Steps To Reproduce:

1. First, install the jimp module : `npm install --save jimp`
2. Second, download a crafted image from the attachment (lottapixel.jpg).
3. Finally, create index.js file as the PoC code below and execute. 

```
var Jimp = require('jimp');

Jimp.read('lottapixel.jpg', (err, lenna) => {
  if (err) throw err;
  lenna
    .resize(256, 256) // resize
    .quality(60) // set JPEG quality
    .greyscale() // set greyscale
    .write('image-small-bw.jpg'); // save
});
```

The output will display the error message like below when the memory is exhausted.
>FATAL ERROR: Ineffective mark-compacts near heap limit Allocation failed - JavaScript heap out of memory

## Patch

> Disable ImageMagick's EXIF orientation.

## Supporting Material/References:

- Pixel flood attack `https://hackerone.com/reports/390`
- Nodejs v13.12.0

# Wrap up

- I contacted the maintainer to let them know: N 
- I opened an issue in the related repository: N

## Impact

Denail of Service

It allows flooding the memory and causing DoS by uploading a crafted image (5kb image), and the Jimp module will tries to allocate 4128062500 pixels into memory.

Module

module name: jimp
version: <=0.10.1

Module Description

The jimp module will load the pixel from the image file to the memory, and processing the image in order to get a new image file such as resize, rotate, blur, etc. The jimp using EXIF data for picture orientation, which was causing run out of memory in the system. The attacker could manipulate the exif data in the image file such as change the image pixel to 64250x64250pixels. If the jimp module loaded the crafted image, it tries to allocate 4128062500 pixels into memory.

Steps To Reproduce:

  1. First, install the jimp module : npm install --save jimp
  2. Second, download a crafted image from the attachment (lottapixel.jpg).
  3. Finally, create index.js file as the PoC code below and execute. 
var Jimp = require('jimp');

Jimp.read('lottapixel.jpg', (err, lenna) => {
  if (err) throw err;
  lenna
    .resize(256, 256) // resize
    .quality(60) // set JPEG quality
    .greyscale() // set greyscale
    .write('image-small-bw.jpg'); // save
});

The output will display the error message like below when the memory is exhausted.

FATAL ERROR: Ineffective mark-compacts near heap limit Allocation failed - JavaScript heap out of memory

Patch

Disable ImageMagick's EXIF orientation.

Supporting Material/References:

  • Pixel flood attack https://hackerone.com/reports/390

activities.message:
@hipstersmoothie based on our email conversation, it looks like the vulnerability might be in the `jpeg-js` package (https://github.com/eugeneware/jpeg-js/issues/46#issuecomment-614672175)?

Can you confirm?
activities.markdown_message:
@hipstersmoothie based on our email conversation, it looks like the vulnerability might be in the jpeg-js package (https://github.com/eugeneware/jpeg-js/issues/46#issuecomment-614672175)?

Can you confirm?

@marcinhoppe Yes, I do.
I tried to load the lottapixel.jpg image with the jpeg-js, and the result is that the node run out of memory.
Look like the problem is in the jpeg-js package which is vulnerable to the memory allocation failed.

The Code:

var jpeg = require('jpeg-js');
var fs = require('fs')
var jpegData = fs.readFileSync('lottapixel.jpg');
var rawImageData = jpeg.decode(jpegData)
console.log(rawImageData);

Regrads,
MAYASEVEN Team

@turtle_shell This should be issue to the jpeg-js package, so what should I do next?

Thank you,
MAYASEVEN Team

activities.message: Hi, I'm one of the maintainers of the `jpeg-js` package. This library from what I can tell doesn't have any external dependencies. Are you saying that the `jpeg-js` suffers from the same kind of memory issue that is present in `jimp`?
activities.markdown_message: Hi, I'm one of the maintainers of the jpeg-js package. This library from what I can tell doesn't have any external dependencies. Are you saying that the jpeg-js suffers from the same kind of memory issue that is present in jimp?

activities.message: Also, I'm not actively maintaining `jpeg-js` at the moment. Can we invite https://github.com/patrickhulce into this thread if the root cause is the `jpeg-js` library?
activities.markdown_message: Also, I'm not actively maintaining jpeg-js at the moment. Can we invite https://github.com/patrickhulce into this thread if the root cause is the jpeg-js library?

activities.message:
Hello @eugeneware,

As we talk above, I have found the dos attack in the `jimp` package, but the jimp maintainers said there is using `jpeg-js` package to be the 3rd party module to loads an image in the jimp. 

I have also examined the jpeg-js, I think the problem is in the prepareComponents function of the decoder.js file. (I analyze this from the error message `jpeg-js.png` above)
activities.markdown_message:
Hello @eugeneware,

As we talk above, I have found the dos attack in the jimp package, but the jimp maintainers said there is using jpeg-js package to be the 3rd party module to loads an image in the jimp.

I have also examined the jpeg-js, I think the problem is in the prepareComponents function of the decoder.js file. (I analyze this from the error message jpeg-js.png above)

activities.message:
Thanks for filing this report!

JPEGs can be validly that large and one could easily craft a solid color valid JPEG with a very small payload that balloons in memory. `jpeg-js` is a synchronous, in-memory JPEG decoder so, IMO, the root security vulnerability is that it is being used on untrusted payloads without limitations.

We can't avoid allocating this much memory for valid JPEGs, but we can at least prevent *unexpected* ballooning memory by default. I'd propose landing https://github.com/eugeneware/jpeg-js/pull/54/files with an additional tweak that turns this behavior on by default and enables a default limit of 10000x10000 pixels (~400MB).
activities.markdown_message:
Thanks for filing this report!

JPEGs can be validly that large and one could easily craft a solid color valid JPEG with a very small payload that balloons in memory. jpeg-js is a synchronous, in-memory JPEG decoder so, IMO, the root security vulnerability is that it is being used on untrusted payloads without limitations.

We can't avoid allocating this much memory for valid JPEGs, but we can at least prevent unexpected ballooning memory by default. I'd propose landing https://github.com/eugeneware/jpeg-js/pull/54/files with an additional tweak that turns this behavior on by default and enables a default limit of 10000x10000 pixels (~400MB).

activities.message:
Hello @patrickhulce,

I agree with you that `the root security vulnerability is that it is being used on untrusted payloads without limitations`, so in my opinion, do we could validate the image file before the create a buffer frame in the memory?

I have tried the difference module such as `gm` module, which used as image processing, the `gm` did validate the `lottapixel.jpg` image and throw the error.
```
Error: Command failed: gm convert: Insufficient image data in file (./lottapixel.jpg).
```

The Code:
```
var gm = require('gm')
  , resizeX = 343
  , resizeY = 257

gm('./lottapixel.jpg')
.blur(30, 20)
.resize(resizeX, resizeY)
.autoOrient()
.write('./2.jpg', function (err) {
	console.log(err)
});
```

Regrads,
MAYASEVEN Team
activities.markdown_message:
Hello @patrickhulce,

I agree with you that the root security vulnerability is that it is being used on untrusted payloads without limitations, so in my opinion, do we could validate the image file before the create a buffer frame in the memory?

I have tried the difference module such as gm module, which used as image processing, the gm did validate the lottapixel.jpg image and throw the error.

Error: Command failed: gm convert: Insufficient image data in file (./lottapixel.jpg).

The Code:

var gm = require('gm')
  , resizeX = 343
  , resizeY = 257

gm('./lottapixel.jpg')
.blur(30, 20)
.resize(resizeX, resizeY)
.autoOrient()
.write('./2.jpg', function (err) {
    console.log(err)
});

Regrads,
MAYASEVEN Team

activities.message: I think that's a pretty good solution to guard against the problem. It's overridable, so people can set the limit lower if they want to be more conservative.
activities.markdown_message: I think that's a pretty good solution to guard against the problem. It's overridable, so people can set the limit lower if they want to be more conservative.

activities.message:
@marcinhoppe Currently, we are pentesting customer system which is using jimp. In case of directing CVE to jimp, we can convince customer for significance and impact of the vulnerability.

According to above statement, I propose to issue 2 CVEs. First one is to jpeg-js and second one is to jimp based on customer point of view.

activities.message:
I think the way it would typically work is that we'd file a CVE in the component that contains the vulnerability: `jpeg-js`. The problem in `jimp` and other libraries or applications that depend on `jpeg-js` would be flagged by SCA tools such as `npm audit`, Snyk, or perhaps GitHub security alerts.

If we issue a CVE for `jimp`, we would have to issue a CVE for every package that depends on `jpeg-js` and there are currently over 92000 of them, according to GitHub. This would flood the SCA tools and would make this information _less_ useful for the community.

Perhaps we could work towards a middle ground solution where we issue a CVE for `jpeg-js` and associate this report with that library, and we can work with `jimp` maintainer to issue a maintainer advisory on GitHub that would cover the vulnerable dependency and you could be credited there, too? 

Of course the credit for a vulnerability found in `jpeg-js` would also go to you.

I'd love to get your feedback about this.
activities.markdown_message:
I think the way it would typically work is that we'd file a CVE in the component that contains the vulnerability: jpeg-js. The problem in jimp and other libraries or applications that depend on jpeg-js would be flagged by SCA tools such as npm audit, Snyk, or perhaps GitHub security alerts.

If we issue a CVE for jimp, we would have to issue a CVE for every package that depends on jpeg-js and there are currently over 92000 of them, according to GitHub. This would flood the SCA tools and would make this information less useful for the community.

Perhaps we could work towards a middle ground solution where we issue a CVE for jpeg-js and associate this report with that library, and we can work with jimp maintainer to issue a maintainer advisory on GitHub that would cover the vulnerable dependency and you could be credited there, too?

Of course the credit for a vulnerability found in jpeg-js would also go to you.

I'd love to get your feedback about this.
